Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Origin of hydrologic responses to earthquakes: constraints from New Zealand, Taiwan, Chile, and USA
Award.AbstractNarration:
Earthquakes generate hydrological responses, such as increases in stream flow and changes in the water level in wells. Such hydrologic responses are important because they provide unique insight into the coupling of hydrologic and tectonic processes at spatial and temporal scales that are otherwise difficult to study. The origin of hydrologic responses to earthquakes has been the subject of controversy, in large part because there are many models to explain observations and few measurements suitable for distinguishing between hypotheses. We will study responses to earthquakes in New Zealand, Chile, Taiwan, and California to test competing hypotheses by 1) compiling observations, 2) collecting new measurements, and 3) developing analytical and numerical models to interpret the hydrological and related geodetic data. We will address the following questions: Does the excess discharge in streams originate from the shallow or deep subsurface? How do the response of deep and groundwater systems differ? Are there different and understandable responses of fracture-dominated rock and unconsolidated materials? Are there permanent changes in properties of the subsurface such as permeability? Are static or dynamic stresses more important for explaining the observed changes?

This project offers an interdisciplinary training opportunity that integrates geophysics and hydrology, and combines modeling and field studies. The proposed work is an international collaboration with scientists in Taiwan, Germany and New Zealand. We will integrate the proposed research with courses taught at UC Berkeley, including freshman seminars, undergraduate-level geodynamics, and graduate level classes. The study of earthquake-induced hydrologic changes has implications for water resources and engineering, including assessing the role of earthquakes in damaging aquifers, affecting underground repositories, and changing water supplies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

 

Groundwater responds to earthquakes. Examples include increased flow in streams and changes in the water level in wells. Such hydrologic responses are important because they provide unique insight into the coupling of hydrologic and tectonic processes at spatial and temporal scales that are otherwise difficult to study.  The origin of hydrologic responses to earthquakes has been the subject of controversy, in large part because there are many models to explain observations and few measurements suitable for distinguishing between hypotheses.

 

This project enabled us to study a variety of hydrological responses to earthquakes around the world, included the USA (the 2016 Napa earthquake), Chile, New Zealand, China, Indonesia, Japan, and Italy. We showed that distant earthquakes can changes permeability – leading to changes in streamflow and water level in wells. We showed that permeability changes can be large, in some cases increasing by three orders of magnitude.

 

We also developed new methodologies for studying the response of groundwater to deformation. We developed new models that account for aquifer leakage and the unsaturated zone. These new models offer an inexpensive tool to continuously monitor aquifer properties.

 

A total of 18 refereed journals articles were published, with another 4 currently in review and an additional 2 in refereed book series.

 

Broader impacts:

 

This project offered interdisciplinary training opportunities for 4 PhD students and 1 postdoctoral researcher.  International collaborations involving individuals and data were established with New Zealand, Taiwan, China, Chile, Japan and Italy. The study of earthquake-induced hydrologic changes has implications for water resources and engineering, including assessing the role of earthquakes in damaging aquifers, affecting underground repositories, and initiating the eruption of mud volcanoes. A case in point is the Lusi mud eruption in Indonesia, a centerpiece of our research efforts. This eruption has caused > $4B is economic losses. Our research documented how and why the eruption began, has evolved, and we forecast its future. Similar analyses were performed for much less damaging mud eruptions in Southern California and Italy.
